Comment: What else? ;-)
Offering the King's Gambit, which I love to play as sharp alternative to the well-known second move Nf3.
Offering the King's Gambit, which I love to play as sharp alternative to the well-known second move Nf3.
The opponents accepts the gambit, so I'm quite lucky - to be honest, I haven't had the time yet to study the King's Gambit declined :)

The usual move, developing and avoiding a queen check on h4. A sharper variant is 3. Bc4, which I haven't really tried out so far, because I'm a bit uncomfortable when my king has to move that early in the game (the opponent can force that simply with 3... Qh4+, but I've heard once that it isn't a good move at all) and hence castling king's side isn't possible anymore.

Bobby Fischer's refutation. In his article "A Bust to the King's Gambit" published in 1961, he suggests this "high-class waiting move" and claims "In my opinion the King's Gambit is busted. It loses by force."
Taking more control of the center and freeing the dark-squared bishop who aims at the pawn f4.
Pinning my knight. The usual move here is g5, trying to hold the pawn on f4.
Getting back the gambit pawn, which feels good ;) Fritz 12 rates this position already as approx. +1 for White! So Black should have better not given away his pawn for free.
Taking my knight. I don't consider this to be a good move - now White has the pair of bishops, his queen can get a nice home on the open f-file, but Black hasn't developed a single piece at all.
According to Fritz, gxf3 is also quite okay, but taking with the queen is more natural.
Developing and aiming my pawn of e4.
Time for one of the key-moves in the King's Gambit! Prepares castling and puts pressure on f7. Fritz likes Nc3 the most.
Putting more pressure on e4...
...so I have to defend it.
? Sacrificing a pawn.
The best move would have been e5 - now Black mustn't capture the bishop on c4 because this would make 10. Qxb7 possible!
Note that the on the first sight attractive because pawn-winning 9... Qxd4+ isn't possible because of the fork on c7: 10. Qxe4+ Nxe4 11. Nxc7+
Aiming at the pawn b2, but leaving f7 *very* weak!
Aiming at the pawn b2, but leaving f7 *very* weak!
Better would have been Bd2, immediately creating a threat on f7.
